awd_titl_txt: Algebraic and Probabilistic Methods in Extremal Combinatorics
awd_abstract_narration:
Extremal combinatorics is an area of mathematics that investigates how large or small configurations of mathematical objects can be under certain constraints. This area is rapidly developing and has close connections to many other areas of mathematics, as well as to theoretical computer science. This research project aims to make progress on questions in extremal combinatorics using methods from algebra and probability theory. The research focuses on some longstanding open questions and conjectures, as well as several related problems. The work will lead to the development of new mathematical tools and techniques and push the limits of known methods. Moreover, through her teaching and mentoring, the investigator strives to encourage students to learn about mathematics and to pursue careers in STEM fields.

The questions studied in this project fall into two rough topic areas. The first of these areas is centered around the slice rank polynomial method that was introduced in 2016. This method has led to several spectacular results in additive combinatorics, but many related questions remain open. The investigator intends to study specific problems exemplifying the current limitations of the slice rank polynomial method. One aim of this project is to find ways to make the method more flexible and more widely applicable. The second topic area of the project concerns the inducibility problem, which was posed over forty years ago and is still wide open. Given a fixed graph H, and a large integer n, this problem asks about the maximum number of induced copies of H that an n-vertex graph can contain. A major open question in this area is the case where the graph H is a path or a cycle. Using probabilistic techniques, the PI plans to investigate this question as well as other inducibility-type problems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Extremal combinatorics is a vibrant area of mathematics with many open problems. This project was aimed at making progress on some of these problems, using algebraic and probabilistic techniques. In other words, these problems were approached with methods from other mathematical areas (namely, algebra and probability theory).

In the course of the project, the PI, partly in collaboration with various coauthors, has proved results on many different problems in extremal combinatorics. For example, in joint work with Zakharov she drastically improved the known bounds for the so-called Erdös-Ginzburg-Ziv Problem, using a combination of algebraic and probabilistic techniques. In her work, she also further developed or adapted previous proof techniques to overcome obstacles in applying them. For example, as part of this project, the PI proved a result about finding distinct-variable solutions to certain types of systems linear equations in large subsets of vector spaces over finite fields. The proof of this result uses an algebraic method, called the slice rank polynomial method, but this method was not directly applicable in this setting. The PI combined the method with probabilistic tools to overcome this obstacle and derive the result.

Over the course of this project, the PI has done research work with four different graduate students. She also has supervised an undergraduate research project. In addition, the PI taught courses introducing students to the field extremal combinatorics and various techniques used in this field. She has also been involved in organizing “women in mathematics” events at MIT, as well as in various outreach activities for high-school students. In particular, over the time of this project, the PI has regularly given talks aimed at high school students introducing them to current research topics in mathematics (partly even discussing results from this project itself).
